rules.name: Cover Letter
rules.overview: A cover letter gives you a chance to speak directly to an employer how your skills and abilities align with the position you are applying for. Unlike a resume that lists your experience, a cover letter lets you tell your story and connect with the person reading it. It is your chance to show that you understand what they are looking for and explain how your skills and experience match their needs.

children.name: Address the reader.
children.description:
Address the name of the person doing the hiring (e.g., Dear Ms. Brown). If you're unable to find the name of the hiring personnel, address the letter as “Hiring Manager” (e.g., Dear Hiring Manager).

Using a specific name is important because it makes your letter personal and shows you have tried to learn about the company.

children.name: Why do you want this job?
children.description:
Tell the reader what interests you about their company and the specific position. Connect their goals to your own work values and career goals. Be as specific as possible and avoid merely copying/pasting the company's mission statement.

Explaining your interest is important to demonstrate that you are not just looking for any job, but specifically want this one.

children.name: What job are you applying for?
children.description:
Start by naming the exact job (cite the reference number if applicable) and the company with the job opening. Tell the reader how you learned about the job opening. Make it clear from the first sentence that you are writing about this specific job. If you received a referral from a recruiter or a person in your professional network, tell the reader that you learned about the position from that person, using their full name.

Naming the job is important in a cover letter because it helps the reader know exactly why you are writing and shows you are paying attention to the details of their posting.

children.name: Why should they want you?
children.description:
In the body paragraphs of the letter, demonstrate that your skills and experiences are a good match for the position. Include specific and detailed experiences that align with what they are looking for. Share brief yet specific stories of similar work you have done. Avoid restating your resume bullet points in paragraph form or highlighting only technical skills using technical jargon.

Sharing relevant experience is important because it helps the employer imagine how you would handle the work their work needs.

children.name: What do you want them to do next?
children.description:
Express your interest in discussing the job further. Restate your interest in the company and show alignment between career goals and the job opportunity.

Stating your desire to discuss the position further demonstrates your enthusiasm for the job, and including specific availability and contact information makes it easier for the reader to act if they are interested in speaking with you.

children.name: Thank the reader.
children.description:
Thank the reader for reviewing your job application. End with a respectful conventional closing, such as “Sincerely” or “Best regards.” Sign with your full name and contact information.

Closing properly shows respect for professional customs and leaves a good final impression.
